questions.question: A 32-year-old woman presents for a routine ultrasound at 28 weeks of gestation. The obstetrician notes an abnormal S/D ratio in the umbilical artery Doppler assessment. Which of the following implications is most likely associated with this finding?

options.A: Low S/D ratio reflects increased resistance in placental blood flow
options.B: Increased resistance to blood flow in the placenta, indicating potential placental insufficiency
options.D: Indicated fetal distress and warrants delivery

questions.explanation: insufficiency insufficiency Explanation: An abnormal S/D ratio indicates increased resistance in placental blood flow, which may affect fetal growth and necessitate closer monitoring. Obstetric Doppler Applications Fetal Well-Being Assessment Crucial for evaluating blood flow in the fetus and placenta. An abnormal S/D ratio in umbilical artery Doppler indicates possible placental insufficiency and necessitates further evaluation. (Option B) High S/D ratio reflects increased resistance in placental blood flow, potentially affecting fetal growth. (Option A ruled out) S/D ratio>3 beyond 28 weeks is a marker of uteroplacental insufficiency Detection of Fetal Anemia Doppler assessment of middle cerebral artery (MCA) blood flow can indicate fetal anaemia. (Option B ruled out) MCA peak systolic velocity (>1.5 MoM) predicts moderate-to-severe fetal anemia Particularly relevant in blood-group allo-immunization cases, where fetal anemia is a severe risk. MCA Doppler in Growth Restriction While helpful for detecting fetal anaemia, its role in managing fetal growth restriction is unclear. An abnormal cerebroplacental ratio may indicate fetal distress, but its impact on delivery timing is not yet established as standard practice. (Option D ruled out) Ductus Venosus Assessment Like MCA Doppler, ductus venosus evaluation has not shown significant benefits in perinatal outcomes. Offers insights into cardiac dysfunction in severe growth restriction but is not routinely recommended for clinical management. Guiding Prenatal Procedures Doppler is instrumental in guiding prenatal interventions, including procedures like cordocentesis.

questions.question: A 30-year-old female patient presents with infertility and undergoes radiological evaluation. Hysterosalpingography (HSG) reveals a "tobacco pouch" appearance and beaded fallopian tubes. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.explanation: Radiological Findings in FGTB Tobacco pouch appearance Pipe stem appearance Beaded appearance Golf club appearance Cogwheel appearance In hydrosalpynx : Dilated fallopian tube with no granulomatous changes Absence of beading or cobblestone patterns.

questions.question: The following sign in breast MRI is characteristic of:
questions.explanation: Intracapsular Rupture : The implant shell breaks, but the fibrous capsule remains intact, preventing silicone from leaking out. On MRI, the collapsed shell appears as multiple wavy lines, resembling linguine. On USG, it appears a stepladder appearance. Extracapsular Rupture : Silicone escapes beyond the fibrous capsule, often seen as the "Snowstorm Sign" on ultrasound. (Option C) Other MRI Signs: "Keyhole Sign" / "Teardrop Sign" : Silicone on both sides of a radial fold suggests rupture. "Salad Oil Sign" : Seen in double-lumen implant rupture with mixing of saline and silicone. Management: Surgical removal is recommended to prevent silicone migration and complications. Fibrocystic breast disease (Option A) : Benign condition with lumpy, painful breasts. Common imaging findings include cystic changes, fibrosis, and adenosis . Fat necrosis of the breast (Option D) : Occurs due to trauma or surgery, presenting as oil cysts, calcifications, or irregular masses on mammography or ultrasound.

questions.question: A 17-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe left scrotal pain radiating to the groin. He describes nausea but denies any trauma. On examination, the left testis is high-riding, and there is tenderness upon palpation. Which imaging modality is preferred in this scenario?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Ultrasonography Explanation: Ultrasonography is the preferred modality for assessing acute scrotal pain. Testicular Imaging: Preferred Modality: (Option C) Ultrasonography (US): Advantages: Non-invasive, well-tolerated, readily available, no ionizing radiation. Doppler Imaging: Essential for assessing blood flow In cases of suspected torsion or infection. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI): Limitations: Longer exam times (Option B ruled out) Less portable Often unavailable Used in equivocal cases. Computed Tomography (Option A): It is less effective at evaluating blood flow compared to ultrasound. X-ray of the pelvis (Option D) : Not useful for evaluating soft tissue structures like the testis or epididymis. Reference: https://geiselmed.dartmouth.edu/radiology/wp-content/uploads/sites/47/2019/07/Avery-Scrotal-emergenc ies-Radics.pdf

questions.question: Scrotal pain with the whirlpool sign on ultrasound is suggestive of:
questions.explanation: layers on color Doppler ultrasound . It is a hallmark sign of testicular torsion , where the spermatic cord twists, cutting off blood supply. Testicular torsion is a urological emergency, requiring immediate detorsion and surgery to prevent testicular loss. Testicular torsion: Finding Incomplete Torsion Complete Torsion Whirlpool Sign A most specific and sensitive sign Present Present Doppler Blood flow is reduced or absent Reduced Absent Elevated Resistive Index (RI) RI > 0.75 indicates compromised blood flow Elevated (RI > 0.75) Not applicable Size Increase Enlargement of the testis and epididymis. Not typically observed Present Echotexture Changes Homogeneous: Early finding (before necrosis) Heterogeneous: Late finding (after 24 hours), suggests necrosis. Typically homogeneous Heterogeneous (after 24 hours) Necrosis Indicators Hypoechoic: represents necrosis. Hyperechoic Regions: represent haemorrhage (if reperfused). Not applicable Present Epididymo-orchitis (Option B) : Shows increased blood flow (hyperemia) , not a whirlpool sign. Varicocele (Option C) : Dilated, tortuous veins with a "bag of worms" appearance on Doppler. Hydrocele (Option D) : Simple fluid collection around the testis, anechoic on ultrasound , with no vascular compromise. Reference: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/whirlpool-sign-testicular-torsion

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a palpable lump in her right breast that she first noticed two weeks ago. The lump is round, mobile, and non-tender on examination. An ultrasound image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: acoustic enhancement are characteristic of a simple cyst. Breast pathology USG-findings USG Simple cyst (Option A) Anechoic with posterior acoustic enhancement Round or ovoid with a smooth hyperechoic wall Complicated cyst (Option C ruled out) Internal echoes Fat-fluid level Oil cyst, galactocoel Internal contents move with change in the position of the breast Complex cyst (Option B ruled out) Hyperechoic thin septations BI-RADS 3:Probably benign, needs follow-up Abscess Ill-defined or well-defined outline Maybe anechoic or low-level internal echoes and posterior enhancement BI-RADS 4/5/6 (Option D ruled out) Hypoechoic mass with irregular wall (spiculated) Taller than wide orientation Intraductal papilloma Dilated duct Well defined nodule BI-RADS 4A/4B/4C: suspicious for malignancy, biopsy advised

questions.question: A 52-year-old woman undergoes routine mammography screening. The report indicates a 1.5 cm spiculated mass with irregular borders in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. The radiologist assigns it a BIRADS 5 category. Which of the following best describes the implication of a BIRADS 5 category on mammography?
questions.explanation: chance of cancer. Urgent biopsy and further management are required. Reference: https://radiologyassistant.nl/breast/bi-rads/bi-rads-for-mammography-and-ultrasound-2013

questions.question: Match the following: Disease Mammography features a. Fibroadenoma (i) Eggshell calcification b. Fat Necrosis (ii) Broken-needle appearance c. Duct ectasia (iii) Teacup calcification d. Fibrocystic disease (iv) Popcorn calcifications
questions.explanation: Condition Mammographic Findings Fibroadenoma Round, well-circumscribed mass with smooth borders; "popcorn" calcifications in older lesions. Benign. Fat Necrosis Irregular, spiculated mass with calcifications; central fat density - Eggshell calcification . Often mimics malignancy. Ductal Carcinoma in Situ (DCIS) Microcalcifications (Segmental distribution of pleomorphic microcalcifications) , often linear or branching, are associated with malignancy. Invasive Ductal Carcinoma Irregular, spiculated mass with poorly defined margins. Microcalcifications and architectural distortion. Fibrocystic disease Teacup calcification represents the layering out of calcific material in the dependent portion of microcysts on a lateral magnification view. Duct ectasia Broken-needle appearance , typical of duct ectasia. Sometimes thicker, more localized calcifications can be seen, giving a ‘lead-pipe’ appearance.

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman is evaluated for a pelvic mass. An ultrasound shows a complex ovarian mass with a Rokitansky nodule and areas of calcification. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: with characteristic findings such as a Rokitansky nodule (echogenic structure projecting into the cyst) and calcifications (e.g., teeth or bones). They may also show fat-fluid levels or acoustic shadows due to sebaceous material or hair. Imaging findings of dermoid cyst Imaging Modality Key Features Ultrasound (US) Cystic mass with an echogenic nodule (Rokitansky nodule) projecting into the lumen. Predominantly echogenic mass with posterior sound attenuation (tip of the iceberg sign) due to sebaceous material and hair. Cystic mass with fine internal echogenic lines (Dot and dash appearance) representing hair. Fluid-fluid level representing sebaceous material floating on fluid. Computed Tomography (CT) Presence of fat and calcifications (e.g., teeth, bones). Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) Sensitive to fat Fat-fluid and fluid-fluid levels, low signal intensity calcifications (e.g., teeth). Rokitansky nodule/dermoid plug attached to the cyst wall. Dermoid cyst" data-author="" data-hash="9779" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/kS0eNuuVm9JrKYWRgEk21744426437.png" /> Endometrioma (Option A) typically presents as a homogenous, low-level echogenic cyst ("chocolate cyst"). Serous cystadenoma (Option B) usually appears as a simple, thin-walled, anechoic cyst. Ovarian carcinoma (Option D) presents with solid components, and irregular walls, and may involve ascites, but doesn't show features typical of dermoids such as fat or calcification. Reference: Grainger and Allison Diagnostic Radiology, Ed.7, page 910.

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pressure. An ultrasound reveals a well-circumscribed, hypoechoic, solid uterine mass with shadowing. What is the most likely imaging diagnosis?
questions.explanation: appear as well-circumscribed, hypoechoic (or heterogeneous), solid masses with posterior shadowing on ultrasound . They may also cause non-tender uterine enlargement and distortion of the uterine contour. Note: Tender enlargement is seen in adenomyosis Endometrial carcinoma (Option A) presents as an irregular mass within the endometrium, often with increased blood flow. An ovarian cyst (Option C) is typically an anechoic structure and doesn't present as a solid mass within the uterus. Adenomyosis (Option D) often shows a thickened, heterogeneously echogenic myometrium with small cysts rather than a well-circumscribed mass. Reference: Grainger and Allison Diagnostic Radiology, Ed.7, page 896, 897.

questions.question: A 42-year-old woman presents with chronic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and menorrhagia. Transvaginal ultrasound shows an enlarged, asymmetrical uterus with sub-endometrial linear striations, 3-mm cysts, and a "rain shower" appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: linear striations (Venetian blind sign) A "rain shower" appearance is suggestive of adenomyosis. Imaging findings in Adenomyosis: Imaging Modality Findings in Adenomyosis Ultrasound (TVUS) Enlarged, globular uterus with asymmetry of the anterior and posterior uterine walls Diffuse echogenic nodules Subendometrial echogenic linear striations (Venetian blind sign) Subendometrial cysts (2-6 mm), seen in 50% of cases Endometrial pseudo widening Poor definition of the endo-myometrial interface Multiple fine areas of attenuation (‘rain shower’ appearance) A speckled pattern of increased vascularity on Color Doppler MRI (T2-weighted images) Ill-defined areas of low myometrial signal intensity due to smooth muscle hyperplasia Diffuse or focal thickening of the junctional zone (JZ) JZ ≥ 12 mm strongly predicts adenomyosis; JZ ≤ 8 mm excludes it High T2 signal intensity foci within low signal myometrium (ectopic endometrial tissue or cystic gland dilatation) (Salt and Pepper appearance) High T2 signal linear striations (finger-like projections) extending from the endometrium into myometrium MRI (T1-weighted images) High T1 signal intensity foci represent small punctate haemorrhages, with a 95% positive predictive value for adenomyosis Uterine fibroids (Option A) typically present as well-circumscribed, solid masses on ultrasound, not associated with the "rain shower" appearance or sub-endometrial cysts. Endometrial polyp (Option B) usually shows a feeder vessel sign (a single feeding artery to the poly that's visible on an USG), but not the sub-endometrial changes seen in adenomyosis. Endometriosis (Option D) involves ectopic endometrial tissue outside the uterus, often associated with ovarian cysts (endometriomas), and does not cause the specific ultrasound features of adenomyosis.

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman with a history of infertility is undergoing evaluation. The scan image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: ultrasound of a uterus. The most likely diagnosis is a septate uterus. On 3D ultrasound, this condition typically shows two endometrial cavities with a normal external uterine contour. This condition is associated with an increased risk of infertility and pregnancy complications, making it a likely cause of this patient’s history of infertility. 3D ultrasound for uterine anomalies: It simultaneously visualizes both the external (serosal surface) and

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman undergoing controlled ovarian hyperstimulation for in vitro fertilization presents with abdominal pain and significant distension. Which of the following is the most likely finding on an ultrasound seen in this patient that helps differentiate it from PCOS?
questions.explanation: Hyperstimulation Syndrome and is indicative of fluid overload in the abdominal cavity while others are typical of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome . Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) Ultrasound Findings : Ovaries exhibit multiple small cysts (2-9 mm) with a "String of pearls " appearance. (Option D ruled out) Ovarian volume typically exceeds 10 mL . (Option B ruled out) Stroma may appear echogenic due to elevated androgen levels. (Option A ruled out) Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS) Ultrasound Findings : Ovaries are markedly enlarged (5-12 cm) with multiple large cysts (theca lutein cysts). Ascites are frequently observed, indicating abdominal fluid accumulation. (Option C) Severe cases may show pleural effusion and signs of fluid overload.

questions.question: Which of the following is not typically associated with IUFD as observed on ultrasound?
questions.explanation: typically associated with IUFD; it may be normal or reduced in such cases. Ultrasound Imaging in Intrauterine Fetal Demise (IUFD) Key Findings : Absent fetal heartbeat (definitive sign of IUFD) Absent fetal movements (strong indicator) Roberts sign: Gas shadow in the heart or great vessels due to postmortem blood degeneration, typically appearing 12–48 hours after death Spalding Sign : Overlapping skull bones suggesting fetal death (Option B ruled out) Maceration : Distortion of fetal anatomy due to decomposition (Option A ruled out) Soft Tissue Edema : Notable when skin thickness exceeds 5 mm (Option D ruled out) Echogenic Amniotic Fluid : Presence of debris in amniotic fluid MRI Imaging Additional Details : Useful when ultrasound findings are unclear. Key Signs : Constricted heart (poorly defined cardiac chambers, abnormal heart signal) Brain ischemia (global ischemic changes in brain tissue) Abnormal globes and effusions (indicate systemic effects) Cord thrombosis (thrombus in the umbilical cord) Etiology and Epidemiology Incidence : Occurs in ~1% of normal pregnancies; many cases are unexplained. Common Causes : Maternal Factors : Gestational hypertension, metabolic disorders Fetal Factors : Major congenital anomalies, umbilical cord complications Placental Pathologies : Significant contributors to IUFD Diagnostic Approach Step Description 1. Initial Assessment Conduct ultrasound to confirm absence of fetal heartbeat and other signs of demise. 2. Follow-Up Imaging Use MRI for further evaluation if ultrasound is inconclusive or more details are needed.

questions.question: A 12-week pregnant patient presents with a nuchal translucency (NT) measurement of 3.2 mm during her first-trimester ultrasound. What is the most appropriate follow-up ultrasound examination to assess for potential anomalies?

options.D: Doppler ultrasound of the umbilical artery

questions.explanation: (aka TIFFA-Targeted imaging for fetal anomalies) at 20 weeks (anomaly scan) is a comprehensive ultrasound essential for evaluating fetal anatomy and detecting potential structural anomalies, especially in cases with increased NT. Nuchal Translucency (NT) Definition: NT refers to the fluid-filled space between the fetal skin and soft tissue at the back of the neck. Measurement: Conducted via ultrasound between 11-14 weeks of gestation in a sagittal plane. Accurate measurement follows specific criteria. Significance: Increased NT: Linked to higher risks of: Fetal Aneuploidy (abnormal chromosome number). Trisomy 21(most common) >monosomy X>Trisomy 18 and 13 Structural Anomalies (especially fetal heart defects). Screening Role: NT is part of first-trimester aneuploidy screening. Threshold for Concern: NT ≥ 3 mm is abnormal and requires further investigation (detailed fetal anatomy survey/ anomaly scan ). (Option A) Outcome: As the fetus develops into the second trimester, nuchal translucency might either: Regress Evolve into: Nuchal edema Cystic hygroma Combined test: ( β -hCG + PAPP-A + NT) Tests Dual test [free b-hCG and PAPP-A (Pregnancy Associated Plasma Protein-A)] + NT scan Time: 11-14 weeks of gestation Anomaly to detect: Down’s syndrome Fetal echocardiography (Option B) is a specialized exam for assessing cardiac structure but is usually performed later if there are specific concerns identified during the anatomy scan. Nuchal translucency re-evaluation at 16 weeks (Option C) is not standard practice; once NT is measured, the focus shifts to the anatomical survey in the second trimester. Doppler ultrasound of the umbilical artery (Option D) primarily detects IUGR in 3rd trimester.

questions.question: An ultrasound scan image of a 30-year-old woman who presented for a routine ultrasound at 6 weeks of gestation is shown below. What is the most significant ultrasound finding in this case?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Lambda sign Explanation: USG shows the lambda sign or twin peak sign, which is characterized by two gestational sacs separated by a thick membrane, and a prominent triangular extension of the chorionic tissue at the junction of the two sacs. This finding is indicative of a dichorionic-diamniotic twin pregnancy . Twin pregnancy: Placenta’s membrane status Timing of cleavage Diamniotic–Dichorionic < 72 hours Diamniotic–Monochorionic Days 4–7 Monoamniotic–Monochorionic Days 8–12 Conjoined Day >13 Note: In dichorionic twin- The lambda sign or twin peak sign is seen. (Option A ruled out) Snowstorm appearance (Option C): It is typically associated with a molar pregnancy. Pseudogestational sac (Option D): It appears as a fluid-filled structure within the uterus that lacks the double decidua sign and typically has an irregular outline. It is commonly associated with ectopic pregnancies or early pregnancy loss. Hence, this option is incorrect.

questions.question: A 33-year-old woman with a history of tubal ligation presents with sudden lower abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She has a positive serum hCG, and transvaginal ultrasound is shown below. What is the most definitive radiological feature confirming the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy in this case?
questions.explanation: ultrasound refers to the increased peripheral vascularity surrounding an extrauterine mass or gestational sac. The presence of this peripheral vascularity, along with the absence of an intrauterine pregnancy, is a definitive radiologic feature of an ectopic pregnancy. Ectopic Pregnancy: Empty extrauterine sac with a hyperechoic ring. Extrauterine yolk sac and/or fetal pole with or without cardiac activity. Inhomogeneous adnexal mass or extrauterine halo-like structure - a probable ectopic pregnancy. Colour Doppler imaging: Placental blood flow within the periphery of an ectopic pregnancy - ring of fire appearance . (Option A) In ruptured ectopic, blood is present in the pouch of Douglas , which shows echoes on USG because of the presence of hemoperitoneum. Lambda sign (Option B): It is seen in dichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancies. Trilaminar appearance (Option C): The trilaminar appearance of the endometrium is normally seen in the late proliferative phase of the menstrual cycle. Double decidual sac sign (Option D): This sign confirms the presence of an intrauterine pregnancy and is not seen in ectopic pregnancy.

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman with a history of recurrent pregnancy loss presents to the Obstetrics clinic at 4.5 weeks gestation for her ultrasound scanning appointment. An image of the transvaginal ultrasound is shown below. shows a well-defined gestational sac with the double decidual sac sign, but no yolk sac or fetal pole is visible. What is the significance of this ultrasound finding?
questions.explanation: suggests an intrauterine pregnancy. At 5 weeks gestation, it is normal to see a gestational sac without the yolk sac or fetal pole, as these structures typically become visible by 5 to 6 weeks. Double decidual sac sign : (Option C) Suggestive of intrauterine pregnancy. (Option A ruled out) Two echogenic rings are seen surrounding the gestational sac, an inner decidua capsularis and an outer decidua parietalis. In between the two decidua is the uterine cavity. Early Pregnancy Ultrasound: Ultrasound is the imaging method of choice. In early pregnancy, transvaginal is more sensitive than trans-abdominal. Decidua is first formed as the thick hyperechoic endometrium. Structures visualized Gestational age (TVS) Key features Gestational sac 4.5 to 5 weeks First sign of pregnancy in an ultrasound Yolk sac 5 to 6 weeks First definitive sign of an intrauterine pregnancy. Fetal

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman with a history of infertility and recurrent pelvic discomfort is undergoing further evaluation with imaging. She has no history of recent infections but had an episode of acute pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) 5 years ago that was treated with antibiotics. The radiological image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Hysterosalpingography (HSG), showing a right-side dilated, tortuous right fallopian tube with no contrast spillage into the peritoneal cavity. The contrast remains confined within the tube, indicating distal blockage. The most likely diagnosis is right hydrosalpinx. Hysterosalpingography It is a radiographic imaging technique. Indication: Infertility evaluation; to assess the endocervical canal, the endometrial cavity, and the fallopian tube lumina and patency. Procedure: Radiopaque contrast material is injected through the cervical canal. It is performed between cycle days 5 and 10. Normal findings: The spill of contrast from the tubes into the peritoneal cavity suggests patency of the fallopian tubes. The endometrial cavity is usually triangular and has a smooth contour. Contraindications: Acute pelvic infection Active uterine bleeding Pregnancy Iodine allergy Images: Normal

questions.question: A 34-year-old woman is undergoing a fertility evaluation. The transvaginal USG image is shown below. Which phase of the menstrual cycle is she most likely in?
questions.explanation: trilaminar appearance of the endometrium. Appearances of Endometrium in Various Phases of the Menstrual Cycle Menstrual and early proliferative phase: (Options A & B ruled out) Thin and brightly echogenic stripe. Late proliferative phase: (Option C) Trilaminar appearance (outer echogenic basal layer, middle hypoechoic functional layer, and an inner echogenic stripe at the central interface) Secretory phase: (Option D ruled out) The thickest can be up to 16 mm. Uniformly echogenic.
